verses.text: Then we turned and went up the road to Bashan. And Og king of Bashan came out against us, he and all his people, to battle at Edrei.
verses.comment: Maintains original sequence; 'went up the road' is a literal rendering of the route up to Bashan.

verses.text: And the LORD said to me, 'Do not be afraid of him, for I have delivered him, all his people, and his land into your hand; you will do to him as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites, who lived at Heshbon.'
verses.comment: Adopts a literal rendering of God's assurance and the comparison with Sihon.

verses.text: So the LORD our God gave Og also, king of Bashan, and all his people into our hand, and we defeated him until not a survivor was left.
verses.comment: ‘Gave... into our hand’ is a literal phrase frequently used for military victory in the OT.

verses.text: And we captured all his cities at that time; there was not a city that we did not take from them: sixty cities, the whole region of Argob, the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
verses.comment: 'Argob' is kept as a transliteration from Hebrew, referring to the specific region.

verses.text: All these were fortified cities with high walls, gates, and bars, besides very many unwalled villages.
verses.comment: Maintains the contrast between fortified cities and unwalled villages.

verses.text: And we devoted them to destruction, as we did to Sihon king of Heshbon, devoting every city to destruction—men, women, and children.
verses.comment: ‘Devoted... to destruction’ translates the Hebrew herem, signifying complete dedication or destruction.

verses.text: But all the livestock and the spoil of the cities, we took as plunder for ourselves.
verses.comment: ‘Plunder’ is used as the plain English equivalent of 'prey' or 'spoil.'

verses.text: So at that time we took the land from the hand of the two kings of the Amorites who were across the Jordan, from the Arnon Valley to Mount Hermon
verses.comment: ‘Arnon Valley’ and ‘Mount Hermon’ kept as literal geographic names.

verses.text: (The Sidonians call Hermon Sirion, while the Amorites call it Senir),
verses.comment: Parenthetical note in original; keeps ancient name variants.

verses.text: all the cities of the plateau, all Gilead, and all Bashan as far as Salecah and Edrei, cities of the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
verses.comment: Geographical listing maintained, modern spelling of city names.

verses.text: (For only Og king of Bashan was left of the remnant of the Rephaim. Behold, his bed was a bed of iron. Is it not in Rabbah of the Ammonites? Nine cubits its length, and four cubits its width, by the common cubit.)
verses.comment: Parenthetical note; measurements kept literal, about 13.5 feet by 6 feet.

verses.text: So this land we took possession of at that time—from Aroer, which is by the Arnon Valley, and half the hill country of Gilead, and its cities, I gave to the Reubenites and the Gadites.
verses.comment: Distribution of territories kept as clear division between tribes.

verses.text: The rest of Gilead, and all Bashan, the kingdom of Og, I gave to the half-tribe of Manasseh (the whole region of Argob, all that part of Bashan; it is called the land of the Rephaim).
verses.comment: 'Land of the Rephaim' preserves ancient terminology for giant peoples.

verses.text: Jair the son of Manasseh took all the region of Argob, as far as the border of the Geshurites and the Maacathites, and called Bashan after his own name, 'Havvoth-jair,' as it is to this day.
verses.comment: ‘Havvoth-jair,’ literally 'villages of Jair,' left as closely transliterated from Hebrew.

verses.text: To Machir I gave Gilead.
verses.comment: Short, literal sentence mirroring the Hebrew structure.

verses.text: And to the Reubenites and the Gadites I gave from Gilead as far as the Arnon Valley, the middle of the valley as a border, as far as the Jabbok, the border of the sons of Ammon;
verses.comment: Geographical boundaries preserved, with modern spellings.

verses.text: the Arabah also, with the Jordan as the border, from Kinnereth as far as the sea of the Arabah, the Salt Sea, under the slopes of Pisgah eastward.
verses.comment: ‘Salt Sea’ for Dead Sea; ‘Kinnereth’ retained for historical accuracy (Sea of Galilee).

verses.text: And I commanded you at that time, saying, 'The LORD your God has given you this land to possess. All your men of valor must cross over, armed, before your brothers, the people of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Men of valor’ is a direct translation for Hebrew 'sons of valor.'

verses.text: But your wives, your little ones, and your livestock (I know you have much livestock) shall stay in your cities which I have given you,
verses.comment: Parenthetical ‘I know you have much livestock’ is retained as in Hebrew.

verses.text: until the LORD gives rest to your brothers, as to you, and they also possess the land which the LORD your God is giving them beyond the Jordan. Then each of you will return to his possession which I have given you.'
verses.comment: ‘Rest’ is a key OT term for settlement in the land.

verses.text: And I commanded Joshua at that time, 'Your eyes have seen all that the LORD your God has done to these two kings; so will the LORD do to all the kingdoms into which you are crossing.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of commission to Joshua.

verses.text: 'You must not fear them, for it is the LORD your God who fights for you.'
verses.comment: Echoes the original emphatic command; 'fights for you' matches Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: And I pleaded with the LORD at that time, saying,
verses.comment: ‘Pleaded’ translates the Hebrew for earnest prayer.

verses.text: 'O Lord GOD, you have begun to show your servant your greatness and your mighty hand. For what god is there in heaven or on earth who can do works like yours, and mighty deeds like yours?
verses.comment: Hebrew ‘Lord YHWH’ rendered ‘Lord GOD’; rhetorical question made clear.

verses.text: Please let me cross over and see the good land beyond the Jordan, that good hill country and Lebanon.'
verses.comment: ‘Good land’ and 'Lebanon' literal renderings of the Hebrew.

verses.text: But the LORD was angry with me because of you and would not listen to me. And the LORD said to me, 'Enough from you; do not speak to me of this matter again.
verses.comment: ‘Enough from you’ is a literal phrase, capturing the finality of God's refusal.

verses.text: 'Go up to the top of Pisgah, and lift up your eyes westward, and northward, and southward, and eastward, and look with your eyes, for you will not cross this Jordan.
verses.comment: Direct speech, relaying the divine prohibition and the alternative offered.

verses.text: But charge Joshua, and encourage him, and strengthen him, for he will cross over before this people, and he will cause them to inherit the land that you will see.'
verses.comment: Maintains three imperative verbs—charge, encourage, strengthen—as per Hebrew.

verses.text: So we remained in the valley opposite Beth-peor.
verses.comment: Literal note of location at end of the chapter.
